metadata.title: Hybrid Nanomaterials through Molecular and Atomic Layer Deposition: Top Down, Bottom up, and In-between Approaches to Make and Modify New Materials

sections.text:
The ability to produce or alter materials to obtain drastically different or
improved properties has been the driving goal of materials science since its inception. Combining multiple elements, compounds, or materials while maintaining the beneficial aspects of each constituent is a complex problem often involving highly interdisciplinary research. Hybrid materials, i.e. materials that incorporate organic and inorganic parts, have become popular in a variety of fields. Though not entirely new, the modern embodiment of hybrid materials has led to a large variety of new materials and techniques to produce them. One of the most recent being combination of atomic layer deposition (ALD), which produces inorganic materials, and molecular layer deposition (MLD), which produces organic materials. Furthermore, a variation on these techniques, commonly referred to as infiltration, has allowed for the modification of a variety of natural and synthetic polymers with surprising results related to their bulk
mechanical properties. In this review three approaches are taken. First, hybrid materials through bottom-up combinations of ALD and MLD are reviewed, focusing on the process and properties of the resulting materials. Second, the modification of biomaterials through coating is discussed, and finally the relatively new concept of vapor phase infiltration is considered as a new and unique method to produce hybrid materials from a top down perspective.
1. Introduction to Hybrid Materials
Hybrid materials comprise essential building blocks that enable the functioning
of the world as we know it. One prominent example is bone, which is composed of collagen as the bioorganic component and calcium based minerals as the inorganic component. Such combinations of dissimilar materials can have completely different characteristics resulting in a hybrid with – as in the case of bone - mechanical properties significantly superior to the properties of the individual components. This example is one among millions that nature has developed through evolution as a response to specific environmental pressures. Evolutionary pressure, however, is not the only motivation to bring about hybrid materials. As early as the 9 th century the Mayans were using a pigment, contemporarily referred to as “Maya Blue,” for their paintings, which was extraordinarily resistant to weathering, thus allowing their survival until the present 1 . The pigment was composed of indigo, prepared from local plants, and palygorskite, a magnesium aluminum phyllosilicate found in the local clay, the combination being a hybrid material with an amazing resistance to bleaching 2 .
Current developments in materials science also aim at trying to merge physical
and/or chemical characteristics of individual components into a balanced intermediate
but rather do so through controlled synthesis techniques developed by modern science. The term ‘hybrid,’ however, can have a variety of meanings and can depend on the field of research. The modern usage began in the 1980s when soft-chemistry techniques capable of producing inorganic materials at low temperature were first developed 3 . In principle, however, modern hybrid materials date back to the beginning of the industrial era when inorganic pigments (PbCrO4, PbCO3, TiO2, etc.) were suspended in solvents for paints; and minerals, clays, and talcs were mixed with early polymers 4 . Since then the concept of ‘hybrid’ has permeated many areas of research. Reference to hybrid materials, hybrid devices, and/or hybrid methods exists in almost all branches of materials science and the associated crossover fields, i.e. chemistry, physics, biochemistry, etc. and can often refer to any material or concept that combines something not normally in that field. More commonly, and for the sake of this review, it refers to the combination of organic and inorganic materials as found in solar cells 5 , polymers composites 6 , thermoplastic polymers 7 , metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) 8 , catalysis 9 , and/or devices and applications in optics 3 , electronics 10 , energy storage, environmental biology, and medicine 11 .
A wide variety of fabrication methods are available in the literature to produce
hybrid materials, most of which are solution based including sol-gel 12 , virus-based selfassembly 13 , electrochemical deposition 14 , foams and colloids 15 , aerogels 16 , and hydrothermal synthesis 17 . Many of the methods have inherent limitations due to the fact that they are solution based which can introduce solution screening, especially in high aspect ratio structures and nanoporous materials, solubility, and temperature limitations. Recently however, atomic layer deposition (ALD), its organic counterpart, molecular layer deposition (MLD), as well as combinations of the two, have led to a wide variety of hybrid organic/inorganic materials with new and/or altered properties when compared to the individual or parent components.

sections.heading: 2. Introduction to ALD/MLD
sections.text:
ALD and MLD are cyclic vapor-phase deposition processes that take advantage
of temporally separated and self-limiting reactions of two or more reactive precursors. Though related, they were largely discovered independently of each other. ALD was originally developed in the 1970s under the name atomic layer epitaxy (ALE) by Suntola et al to deposit ZnS for electroluminescent displays, with the first commercial device operating in the Helsinki airport from 1983 to 1998 18, 19 . A similar approach was also reported in the former Soviet Union, which has recently led to a debate about the original discovery 20 . The more common acronym “ALD” was not widely adopted until the early 2000s as the semiconductor industry began to develop high-κ dielectrics with the technique. The materials deposited by “ALE” were usually amorphous or polycrystalline and no-longer fit the definition of epitaxial. Therefore the term “deposition” was adopted as a more accurate description of the technique. MLD has more recent origins dating to 1991 when Yoshimura et al deposited polyimide films and was first referred to as either alternating vapor deposition, vapor deposition polymerization, or layer-by-layer growth 21 . Similar to ALD, this process relies on temporal separation of the precursors supplied in the vapor phase and their selfterminating surface reaction. Rather than using metal containing precursors MLD processes use bi-functional monomers that undergo condensation polymerization reactions thus being an organic counterpart of ALD 22 . MLD processes can also deposit ultrathin films conformally over high-aspect ratio structures with molecular scale control.
Several important reviews have been published that cover the details of the
surface chemistry for both ALD 23, 24 and MLD 22, 25 , the wide variety of metal organic precursors 26, 27 , the available noble metal processes 28 , the available MLD processes 29 ,
the fabrication of nanomaterials 30-32 , reactions with polymer substrates 33 , functionalization of nanoparticles 34 , the chemistry of hybrid MLD materials 35 , and various applications in Li + storage systems 36 . For more details about any particular process, precursor, or application the reader is encouraged to follow these references. Here we will focus on the fabrication of hybrid materials and their various applications including a discussion of the recently developed vapor phase infiltration. This review will, for the sake of completeness, discuss the basics of the two processes, i.e. ALD and MLD, focused on their combination for synthesizing hybrid materials.
ALD can be considered a similar, though chemically distinct, case of chemical
vapor deposition (CVD), where the reaction is separated into two self-limiting halfreactions, an illustration of which can be found in Figure 1 37 . Between each halfreaction is an essential purge step, step 3 and 6 in Figure 1, that prevents any parasitic gas phase reactions (i.e. parasitic CVD), removes unreacted precursors, and any byproducts of the reaction. Under no circumstances should the two reactive precursors reside in the reaction space at the same time. Furthermore, ALD processes are often performed at significantly lower temperatures than the related CVD processes, which typically rely on high temperatures to thermally decompose the precursor at the substrate surface with growth rates related to the flux of the precursor at the substrate. The growth rate of an ALD process is more complicated to define compared to CVD processes and often operates in a window, where the concentration of the precursors per pulse, the temperature, and purge times are balanced such that the growth rate per cycle (GPC) is stable. Nominally the GPC should be one monolayer per cycle, in practice however the GPC can vary from 0.1 Å/cycle to 2 Å/cycle depending on the precursor reactivity and size, process parameters, and the progress of nucleation on the substrate surface.
The self-limiting and chemistry dependent nature of ALD reactions also allows
several unique features, namely, conformality and surface selectivity. Compared to other deposition processes ALD has the ability to deposit in, on, and/or over very complicated nanostructures 30, 36 . This ability has been one of the driving forces in academic research using ALD 25, 30 . More recently the surface selectivity of ALD precursors has been used in combination with self-assembled monolayers 38 or through other types of chemical modification of what would otherwise be an inactive surface or substrate 39 forcing deposition in predefined areas and leaving the rest of the substrate more-or-less clean.
In principle, all of the mentioned characteristics of ALD are found in MLD as
well as any combination of the two techniques. In fact, the difference between what is MLD and what is ALD may be difficult to describe and speaks to the rather broad definition of hybrid mentioned earlier. Strictly speaking MLD would only include processes such that the material produced is entirely organic such as polyamide 21, 40-42 , polyimide 21, 43 , polyurea 44 , polythiourea 45 , polyurethane 46 , polyazomethine 47 , and polyethylene terephthalate 48 , all of which have been reviewed in greater detail 29 . Also referred to as MLD, though is a hybrid of ALD and MLD, are the metal alkoxides or socalled ‘cones’ due to their similarity to silicone, the first of which was alucone 49, 50 . After this initial publication followed zincone 51, 52 , titanicone 53 , zircone 54 , as-well-as several variant precursors and processes for the materials listed here. Some of the properties of these hybrid materials were shown to be tunable and seem promising for a large variety of applications that will be described in greater detail below.
The final and most recent adaptation of ALD/MLD techniques towards the
discovery and/or enhancement of new materials and properties is the use of infiltration. Where ALD and MLD techniques take a bottom up approach toward the fabrication of hybrid materials it is also possible to consider a top down approach. This has been
demonstrated with several soft material substrates and given the name multiple pulse infiltration, pulsed vapor infiltration, sequential vapor infiltration, or atomic layer deposition/infiltration 55, 56 . In this technique standard precursors are given long exposure times to a soft substrate allowing for diffusion into the material, chemical modification of the structure, and the creation of a hybrid organic/inorganic material or a hybrid area in a material.
This review is broken up into three main sections. In the first part we review
bottom up processes where thin-films are grown nominally one monolayer at a time. Second we consider hybrid materials created by applying inorganic coatings to a variety of both synthetic and bioorganic substrates. Finally the third section gives an overview of top down approaches where natural or synthesized polymers and soft materials are modified with metal-organic precursors through the recently developed infiltration techniques.

sections.heading: 3. Bottom Up: Hybrid Materials through ALD/MLD
sections.text:
Bottom-up approaches have become ubiquitous in almost all areas of physical
and chemical research as per the development of fabrication techniques for tens of thousands of different types of nanostructures. A variety of techniques have been developed and enable the production of quantum dots, nanowires, and thin films, as well as many other derivative or hybrid structures (i.e., core-shell nanostructures 57 , nanoribbons 58 , etc.). Often a single technique can produce a variety of structures by tuning the multiplicity of defining parameters or by choosing a sacrificial high-aspect ratio substrate. As mentioned previously in reference to hybrid materials (final paragraph, section 1), but also true with respect to bottom-up nanostructure fabrication, a large variety of solution-based methods are available and able to produce this rather
broad-spectrum of nanostructures. Often these same techniques also allow hybrid versions of the same structures.
This also holds true for the large variety of both physical and chemical thin-film
growth techniques (i.e. sputtering, evaporation, CVD, etc.). Originally motivated by the needs of the semi-conductor industry to pack more transistors per unit area, though subsequently adopted by almost every major manufacturing process from sunglasses to solar cells, academically these techniques are also used to further add to the already large catalogue of nanostructures. For example it is well known that CVD techniques can produce nanowires of various materials through the use of Au catalysts or aligned multi-wall carbon nanotubes through plasma-enhanced CVD 59, 60 . However, due to the often high-temperatures involved or harsh plasma environment, the additional introduction of organic components can be difficult. Here combination ALD/MLD techniques offer a unique and elegant solution. The low temperature and chemistrybased nature of these processes allow for easy introduction of a large variety of organic molecules. The addition of these organic components increases the potential for tunability, new functionality, and potentially allows for the discovery of a whole new range of materials. Furthermore the extreme conformality allows for the adoption of the same high-aspect ratio sacrificial templates mentioned earlier, leading to further application potential.
3.1 Self-Assembled Monolayers
Among the first demonstrations of hybrid materials synthesis through
ALD/MLD were those using self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) as the organic component in nanolaminate structures. Subsequently, significant effort has been invested to produce inorganic as well as hybrid organic/inorganic superlattices entirely
through ALD and/or MLD processes. Typically the combination of SAM and ALD aimed at improving the electrical and mechanical properties of common dielectric materials in order to make them suitable for flexible electronics.
The first hybrid of ALD and SAMs used a combination of 7-
octenyltrichlorosilane (7-OTS) and TiO2 deposited from titanium isopropoxide (TIP) and H2O. The 7-OTS SAM layer was made using a three-step process where the 7-OTS was mixed with H2O and exposed to a Si/SiO2 surface. Subsequently, it reacted with O3 to convert the C=C groups to carboxylic acid groups. Finally the carboxylic acid group was coupled with titanium by exposure to TIP. The growth rate of this process was shown to be 11 Å/cycle. Nanolaminates of TiO2/7-OTS were made by alternating between the organic process described here and the standard TIP/H2O process for TiO2. The electrical properties of the SAMs and the nanolaminates were tested through the fabrication of sandwiched Pt/SAM/Pt as well as organic pentacene thin-film transistors. The organic layer was shown to have a low leakage current and a dielectric constant of 17 at 1 MHz 61
. A similar study was conducted by alternating TiO2 and Al2O3 between
the 7-OTS layers in the sequence 7-OTS/TiO2/7-OTS/Al2O3. Flexible transistors were fabricated with various supercycle thicknesses and a wide variety of transistor based electrical properties were tested. 62 Similar results were shown for thin-film organic transistors based on 7-OTS and ZrO2 63 .
In analogy, ZnO and TiO2 cross-linked polydiacetylene novel hybrid materials
were deposited using DEZ, TiCl4, and 2,4 hexadiyne-1,6-diol, respectively 64, 65 . In both cases the films showed linear growth rates with respect to the number of cycles of 5.2 Å/cycle in the case of DEZ and 6 Å/cycle for TiO2. Temperature windows were not reported for either material, however, the authors noted that depositions were conducted at low temperatures between 100°C and 150°C. The electrical properties of the DEZ cross-linked polydiacetylene were tested in a thin-film transistor configuration. It was
shown that this material behaves as n-type semiconductor with a high electron mobility of greater than 1.3 Vcm 2 V -1 s, an on/off ratio of 10 6 , and a gate leakage current below 10 -10 A.
In an attempt to improve the leakage current of Ta2O5, which has a high
dielectric constant (20-25 depending on fabrication method, purity, and crystallinity), but suffers from the aforementioned leakage current, a nanolaminate of Ta2O5/polyimide was fabricated 66 . The hybrid structure was optimized and shown to have a leakage current density of 1x10 -8 Acm -2 at 1 MVcm -1 for five stacks of 5nm Ta2O5 + 15 nm of polyimide, as compared to 5x10 -4 Acm -2 at 1 MVcm -1 and 4x10 -5 Acm -2 at 1 MVcm -1
for the pure Ta2O5 and polyimide respectively. The mechanical
properties of the nanolaminates were also tested through nano indentation and were shown to become softer as the polyimide content was increased.
Other applications of SAMs in combination with ALD include the development
of a technique referred to as area-selective ALD or AS-ALD 67 . This technique is reminiscent of more traditional top-down approaches, discussed in the following section, where certain areas of a substrate are pre-selected to either enhance or inhibit growth of a material by ALD. In AS-ALD SAMs have been used to chemically modify parts of a substrate so that their terminal groups either allow growth in that area or prevent it. Originally shown only for inorganic ALD techniques, the same technique has also been applied to MLD allowing for AS-MLD 68
3.2 Alucone and Zincone
Aluminum alkoxides, called alucones were originally developed through a sol-
gel technique 69 , and represent the first and most researched hybrid materials fabricated through hybrid MLD/ALD processes. Initial development through ALD/MLD of the
hybrid material alucone started with George’s group 49 using tri-methyl aluminum (TMA) and the diol ethylene glycol (EG) as shown in Figure 2 and is later referred to as an AB process. The growth rate per cycle (GPC) of these films was shown to be highly dependent on the process temperature varying from 4 Å/cycle at 85°C down to 0.4 Å/cycle at 175°C 49 . In-situ FTIR and quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) were used to monitor the process and showed that some amount of non-linear growth, where the TMA and EG can diffuse into the subsurface regions and react with unreacted –OH and –AlCH3 groups from previous cycles. Ex-situ FTIR, XPS, XRR, and TEM confirmed the physical and chemical structure of the film and showed that the material has a –O– CH2–CH2–O– backbone, the CH2 presence, C–C, and C–O stretching bands, as-well-as significant differences in the density of alucone (1.5 g/cm 3 ) as compared to the standard Al2O3 (2.9 g/cm 3 ). Unfortunately these films were shown to be unstable in the long term. After ~200h the film thickness decreased by around 20%. This was most likely due to reactions with atmospheric H2O that slowly diffuses into and reacts with the film. Capping the film with ALD deposited SiO2 prevented this degradation providing further evidence of these slow post-reactions.
A three-step alucone process (ABC) was developed using TMA, ethanolamine
(EA), and maleic anhydride (MA) further expanding the possibilities of available organic reactants 50, 70 . The GPC was much higher than the two-step process but also highly dependent on the process temperature varying from 24 Å/cycle at 90°C down to 4 Å/cycle at 170°C. Interestingly the ring structure of the MA was shown to open during the reaction, with the XPS and FTIR spectra being more consistent with polyamide than polyimide. Further study of the reaction mechanism showed that TMA diffusion and non-self-limiting behavior in the steady state growth region led to the higher than usual GPC. For films grown at 130°C only a ~5% decrease in thickness
after the first few days of growth was observed, a significant improvement over the two step process. 70
Carboxylic acids, such as benzoic, fumaric, and maleic acid, were also used as
the organic component in the alucone process 71, 72 . The GPC was dependent on the chosen carboxylic acid precursor as well as the temperature of the reaction varying from as high as 11.9 Å/cycle to 2.4 Å/cycle. The density of the films was shown to be less than that of Al2O3 varying from 1.4-2.9 g/cm 3 . The films were amorphous and FTIR measurements confirmed the presence of carboxylate groups in the films.
A heterobifunctional allyl alcohol, glycidol, was also used as the organic
component in such a reaction 73 . Again the GPC was highly dependent on both the temperature and the purge times with a rather stable value of 1.3 Å/cycle at 125°C. Dramatic increases in the GPC were seen at lower temperatures and purge times below 20 s. The reaction mechanisms were monitored through FTIR with the glycidol shown to react with the –CH3 groups of the TMA. Interestingly the chemistry also seemed to be dependent on the Lewis acidity of the TMA as an attempted similar reaction with diethyl zinc (DEZ) resulted in limited growth. Compared to the previously used organic components glycidol required a significant attention to the process parameters in order to keep the reaction in the self-limiting regime.
Amine containing alucone films were shown using triethanolamine (TEA) 74 . The
GPC was reported as 1.3 Å/cycle. Similar analysis techniques as discussed above were used to confirm the presence of the amine species in the film after deposition.
The wide variety of applicable organic precursors indicates the great potential
for tunability of these materials. By combining one or more organic precursors or the ratio of ALD (i.e. TMA/H2O) to MLD (i.e. TMA/organic) cycles 75 , it has been shown that the mechanical properties of the resulting film are highly tunable. For example by comparing the mechanical properties of the AB process to the ABC process with TMA,
EA and MA it was found that the elastic modulus was 36.8±5.6 GPa and 13.2±5.0 GPa, respectively 76 . Differences in the material hardness were also found. The AB process produced films with 0.47±0.07 GPa hardness, while the ABC process led to films with a hardness of 0.27±0.10 GPa. The thermomechanical properties of the AB processed films were also studied, resulting in a measured coefficient of thermal expansion of 12.6 ppm °C -1 upon heating and 7.1 ppm °C -1 upon cooling. Further tunability was shown by alloying the hybrid AB process with inorganic ALD deposited Al2O3 by controlling the relative number of hybrid to inorganic cycles (i.e TMA/H2O:TMA/EG). As a result, the mechanical and optical properties of the composite material were tunable, see Figure 3a and 3b, with the upper and lower limits being controlled by the law of mixtures 75 . The hardness, elastic modulus, index of refraction, and density were all increasing as the ratio of hybrid to inorganic cycles was changed from 1:3 to 1:1 and finally to 3:1. This example illustrates the power of the ALD/MLD techniques for growing hybrid thin films with tunable properties and control at the molecular level. Eventually, further process and precursor development may enable seamless control of the physical properties ranging from pure polymer-like to pure inorganic for the benefit of a variety of emerging applications.
Similar to Alucone but not necessarily a large enough group to warrant their
own section are hybrid materials grown with metal quinolines such as Alq3, Znq2, and Tiq4 where q=8-hydroquinoline 77, 78 . When TMA is paired with one of the quinolines the GPC was shown to be fairly high varying from 0.4 nm – 0.7 nm, decreasing with temperature. All three combinations were shown to have photoluminescence though the TMA/Tiq4 was significantly lower than TMA/Alq3 and TMA/Znq2. A follow up study was done with a more detailed photoluminescence study by creating monolayers of Alq3 using 8-hydroxyquinoline 78 .
3.2.1 Zincone
Similar to alucone though perhaps more interesting in terms of applications and
tunability, is zinc alkoxide or zincone, which was first demonstrated using DEZ and EG 51, 52 . Self-limiting growth was again highly dependent on process temperature with the GPC varying from 4 Å/cycle at 90°C to 0.25 Å/cycle at 170°C. In-situ analysis using FTIR and QCM was used to confirm the reaction chemistry and the presence of the organic –O–CH2–CH2–O– backbone comparable to the structure of alucone. Initially, after the deposition, the films were shown to absorb atmospheric H2O, but were otherwise more stable than the analogously processed alucone films.
ALD ZnO intrinsically shows a high electrical conductivity. Based on this fact,
in an attempt to make a conductive hybrid organic material, zincone was grown using a combination of DEZ and the aromatic diol hydroquinone (HQ), the schematic of which is shown in Figure 4 79 . It was expected that the structure of the conjugated double bonds would lead to tunable electron conductivity, unfortunately the material proved to be electrically insulating 80 . Surprisingly however, the electrical and thermal conduction become more interesting when zincone is alloyed with ZnO. Four point probe and frequency-dependent time-domain thermoreflectance measurements of ALD ZnO, alloys of ALD ZnO and HQ zincone, and EG zincone showed significant differences in both their electrical and thermal conductivities 80 . Purely inorganic ZnO had a conductivity of 20 Scm -1 after UV exposure, though the authors noted a spread of values in the literature mostly related to process parameters. Zincone with EG and HQ as the organic component were shown to be insulating, however, upon alloying HQ zincone with ALD ZnO high electrical conductivities were observed. Figure 5 shows the conductivities for a variety of alloys with the best being a 2:2 alloy (i.e DEZ/H2O:DEZ/HQ) an electrical conductivity of 200 Scm -1 was found. This high
conductivity was largely due to electron donation from the aromatic diol HQ. The mechanical properties were also studied and these materials were shown to be more flexible than the parent materials. They also were optically transparent until the band gap was approached.
Studies of the thermal conductivity also revealed interesting behavior. One-to-
one alloys of DEZ/H2O:DEZ/HQ had ultralow thermal conductivity and volumetric heat capacities as compared to zincone films made with EG and HQ 81 . The alloy film showed a room temperature volumetric heat capacity of 0.590 Jg -1 K -1 compared to 1.316 Jg -1 K -1 for DEZ/EG and 1.605 Jg -1 K -1 for DEZ/HQ. Similarly, the thermal conductivity of the alloy was significantly lower than zincone itself with a value of 0.125 WmK -1 compared to 0.325 WmK -1 for DEZ/EG and 0.225 WmK -1 for DEZ/HQ. Figure 6a and 6b summarize this data.
Additionally the heterobifunctional precursor 4-aminophenol (AP) was also
explored as the organic component for obtaining zincone and combined with standard ALD of ZnO to make a hybrid superlattice 82, 83 . The AP molecule possesses a rigid benzene backbone with two functional groups, one –OH, and one –NH2. A linear GPC of ~1.2 Å/cycle was observed over a wide temperature window between 150°C to 350°C. The films were characterized by XPS, AFM, and XRD and were proven to contain the expected amine groups, were fairly smooth, and had temperature dependent crystallinity 82 . The hybrid superlattice had mechanical properties tunable with the ratio of organic to inorganic process fractions, similar to the alucone materials discussed above 83 .
The potential power of this material lies in its inherent tunability, not only the
mechanical properties, as is the case with alucone, but also its electrical and thermal conductivities. By changing the organic component, alloying with the parent oxide, and/or combining this hybrid material with further materials a large window of possible
combinations becomes available, allowing the design and fabrication of materials tailored for an anticipated application. In contrast to alucone-based hybrids, zincone adds to the portfolio of properties through which a specific and possibly pre-determined set of material requirements can be selected. The work reviewed here is merely the foundation that should lead to a rather large set of materials possibilities
3.3 Titanicone, Zircone, and Hafnicone
A third variant of the metal alkoxides, titanium alkoxide or titanicone,
was deposited using titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) and either the diol EG or the triol glycerol 53 . Again, a strong dependence on the process temperature and the type of the organic component was observed. Titanicone deposited with EG had a fairly stable growth window with a GPC of 5.4 Å/cycle between 90°C and 135°C. In contrast, upon use of glycerol the GPC was dependent on the reaction temperature and decreased from 2.8 Å/cycle at 130°C to 2.1 Å/cycle at 210°C. The density of the material was independent of the precursor and the process parameters with a value of ~1.8 g/cm 3 . Similar to zincone the electrical properties of titanicone were tunable, though the tunability was based on a post-process annealing temperature, rather than alloying with the parent oxide. The sheet resistance decreased drastically, reaching a minimum of 2.2×10 4 Ω/☐ upon treatment at 800°C. Raman spectroscopy confirmed the presence of domains of sp 2 -graphitic carbon, obviously due to pyrolysis of the organic component, making a composite of graphite embedded in TiO2 and offering a new method of tunability to the hybrid material.
Using this annealing method, a nitrogen doped TiO2 was prepared by a ABCB
process using TiCl4, hetero-bifunctional ethanolamine (EA), and homo-bifunctional malonyl chloride (MC) 84 , shown in Figure 7. The process was developed at 100°C and had a GPC of ~ 6 Å/cycle. The combination of the hetero and homo bifunctional
precursors allowed preferential reaction between the TiCl4 and hydroxyl on the one hand and acyl chloride and amine groups on the other. The choice of the organic precursors and their length allowed stretching the distance between the individual Ti moieties to an extreme with the length of the organic linkers. After the process the films were annealed at 600°C which removed the organic components and created a N-doped TiO2. More promisingly this process was also shown to work with TMA giving further possibilities for multifold mixing of organics and inorganics during the process.
Related to titanicone is zirconium alkoxide or zircone, which was deposited
using zirconium tert-butoxide (ZTB) and EG 54 . Also here, the GPC was temperature dependent with a value of 1.6 Å/cycle at 195°C to 0.3 Å/cycle at 105°C. The density of zircone was independent of the process temperature ~2.17 g/cm 3 , which is around half of that of pure ZrO2 (~4.0 g/cm 3 ). The films were stable over time with only a ~3% decrease in thickness during a one month period. Similar to the Al2O3/alucone system, the properties of alloys of ZrO2 and zircone were also studied. The index of refraction, elastic modulus, electrical properties, and density were all tunable by varying the ratio of ZTB/H2O:ZTB/EG 54 .
The final metal alkoxides related to titanium and zirconium based hybrid
materials is hafnicone 85 . Hafnicone was grown with tetrakis(dimethylamido)hafnium (TDMAH) and EG. imilar to the other metal al o ides the G was shown to be a function of the deposition temperatures arying from /cycle at to
/cycle at 205 °C. The density of the film was shown to be consistent over the varying
growth temperatures ∼3.0 g/cm3. The organic films were alloyed with their inorganic counter part, i.e. HfO2, and the electron density was shown to be tunable as a function of alloy ratio from 8.2 × 10 23 e − /cm 3 for pure hafnicone MLD to 2.4 × 10 24 e − /cm 3 , indicating the possibility of a wide range of tunable properties such as refractive index, dielectric constant, and mechanical properties.
Much like zincone the possible applications derived from the tunable properties,
in this case the electrical and possibly the photoelectric, of titanicone make it highly attractive for a variety of systems. The initial research reviewed here leaves a vast amount of room for future work aimed at taking advantage of this tunability, as-well-as the completely unexplored possibility of alloying with its parent material, the strategy that lead to interesting thermal and electrical behavior in zincone, or possibly alloying with other materials, i.e. alucone, zincone, etc., which could further expand both the discovery of new and interesting materials properties.
3.4 Applications of the Metalcones
The use of ALD and MLD for synthesis of metal alkoxides has emerged rather
recently and the initial applications of those materials have been limited and largely relegated to their parent materials’ applications, most li ely representing the foundation of future wor to launch from ome of the first applications of the ‘cones’ was to coat inorganic nanoparticles to confirm the optimized process parameters for the design of a fluidized bed reactor 86 . Further study however focused on decomposing the organic components. Alucone was deposited on SiO2 NPs and then the organic constituent was decomposed by either soaking the particles for several days in water or through oxidation in air at either 400°C and 1000°C 87 . The pore size of the resulting ultrathin micro and mesoporous Al2O3 films was dependent on the method for removal of the organics. Soaking in water resulted in pore sizes between ~0.6 nm and 4.3 nm. The resulting porosity was also temperature dependent with a higher concentration of mesopores being fabricated upon annealing at higher temperatures 88 .
Needless to say that this strategy has application potential in the fabrication of
supported metal catalysts. Pt decorated SiO2 particles were coated with alucone.
Subsequent thermal decomposition led to a porous alumina coating over the Pt catalysts. The authors reported that the coated Pt particles were more stable and resisted calcination up to 800°C. Unfortunately, the porous alumina coating also reduced their catalytic activity. 88 To combat this loss the same group attempted to control the porosity by using different sized organic molecules during the deposition 89 . By depositing an alucone film with longer carbon chains an increase in the pore diameter from 0.6 nm to 0.8 nm was observed. However, the stability of the ABC alucone was considered a potential problem. The authors noted that some 17 nm pores were measured and were most likely due to local collapse of the structure.
Diffusion mechanisms of Cu atoms were compared by preparing CuO nanowires
that were coated either with alucone or with Al2O3. Several TEM images of the coated nanowires are shown in Figure 8. Similar to the nanoparticle research above, after annealing the alucone was converted to porous Al2O3. The encapsulated CuO was reduced to Cu and diffused through the porous Al2O3 to form surface nanoparticles at the mouths of the pores. The size and the distribution of the resulting nanoparticles were shown to be controllable by varying the thickness of the porous layer. During the annealing process the Cu nanowire first breaks into nanoparticles due to Rayleigh instability. The formation of the nanoparticles was explained by the outward diffusion of Cu through the small pore size, tortuosity of the micropores in the film, and the high thermal stress created at the interface between Cu/Al2O3. At the pore mouth the Cu was oxidized to CuO, which nucleated and continued growing. When coated with Al2O3, however, diffusion would only happen at cracks or defects in the coating that formed due to mechanical stress occurring at the high annealing temperatures 90 .
The photocatalytic properties of porous TiO2 and a porous N-doped TiO2 were
studied using titanicone as the base material, which was then annealed similar to the previously discussed materials. Using the standard TiCl4/EG chemistry, porous films
were made on planar substrates as-well-as on Si NWs 91 . Porphyrin absorption and photodegradation studies were conducted to study the photocatalytic behavior and it was shown to be dependent on the thickness of the film and the annealing temperature. In all cases the annealed titanicone outperformed TiO2 films deposited from TiCl4 and H2O. Furthermore, the intermediate amorphous-crystalline phase was shown to be important in terms of designing these photocatalytic materials. As described in section 3.3, an N-doped TiO2 was fabricated through an ABCB process. This material was deposited onto carbon nanocoils (CNCs), Figure 9(a-d) and annealed in air at various temperatures. The presence of amine (nitrogen) in the organic part enabled the intrinsic N-doping of TiO2 upon calcination. The photocatalytic activity, Figure 9e and 9f, was measured by evaluating the photodegradation of methylene blue upon exposure to visible light. A peak decomposition rate was shown for CNCs coated with 200 cycles and annealed at 350°C 84 .
Striking results in the change of mechanical behavior of sheets of multiwalled
carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were seen when they were coated with various metal alkoxides. MWNCTS were fabricated through compression of a CVD formed MWCNT aerogel that were then coated with two types of alucone, one based on EG the other based on GL, titanicone (TiCl4/GL), and zincone (diethyl zinc/GL). The resulting hybrid material was studied in terms of the conformality and quality of the coating and the resulting mechanical behavior. Most interestingly, in almost all cases, the hybrid material showed significant degradation of the failure strain parallel to the sheet orientation for all of the materials 92 . Some small, material dependent, improvements in the Young’s modulus were measured, a increase for GL based alucone and a 13.5x increase for EG based alucone but otherwise leaving lot of space for further investigation and optimization.

sections.heading: 4 Coating Soft Materials-Hybrid Interfaces
sections.text:
Related to the bottom up process discussed in chapter 3 is coating organic and
bioorganic substrates with inorganic materials to create hybrid materials. The composite system, often containing a sharp interface between the two components, can exhibit new and/or enhanced functionality. Depending on individual disciplines the nature of whether a material is organic, bioorganic, or a biomaterial can differ drastically and is usually a function of whether the material is protein based or merely widely available in nature. For the sake of this section of the review biomaterials will be considered any material produced by nature including, protein based, polysaccharide based (i.e. cellulose), or artificially obtained through the self-assembly of bioorganic molecules such as peptides. What unites these materials is that they have been uniquely designed through millions of years of evolution to be incredibly robust within their own environment. Within temperature, humidity, and atmospheric limits these materials are often exceptionally designed and lack a synthetic analogue aimed at the same purpose. Taking advantage of these designs, while avoiding their limits, for modern applications has been difficult and has since spawned an entire discipline aptly named bio-mimicry, the idea of this discipline being to use the materials of nature as inspiration when solving modern material problems.
As ALD and MLD process temperatures were developed below 100°C
applications with biomaterials began to appear 93 . Initially these studies were driven by shear curiosity and resulted in novel nanostructures. Since these initial studies hybrid biomaterials have found their way into a variety of applications from optical gratings to energy storage and will be discussed here.

sections.heading: 4.1 Viruses and Proteins
sections.text:
One of the first biomaterials used with ALD was the tobacco mosaic virus
(TMV), which incidentally, was also one of the first viruses to be studied in general. The TMV structure is a 300 nm long protein tube with a diameter of 18 nm and contains a central channel with a diameter of 4 nm, a schematic and TEM images can be seen in Figure 10(a-f). Furthermore, TMV is stable up to 80°C and has been shown to easily survive the low pressures needed for ALD processing. Besides the simple structure and stability of TMV can be aligned on various inorganic substrates, including patterned substrates, thus making it a simple and versatile structure for study 94, 95 . The first studies of ALD coatings on were done at the exceedingly low temperature of 35°C with either TMA or TIP and water as the second precursor in both cases 96, 97 . Surprisingly, after the deposition process no morphological changes were witnessed, the diameter of the TMV remained 18 nm and metal oxide was deposited on both the outer surface as well as in the channel confirming that the shape of the structure was not damaged due to vacuum exposure and proving, once again, that ALD can conformally coat even the most stringent geometries.
The ability to make nanostructures with and/or modify the outer amino acid shell
allows a wide array of potential applications 98-103 . Combined with the ability to selectively pattern substrates significantly broadens those possibilities. To take advantage of these possibilities while avoiding the temperature limitations of TMV a new method was developed where first the TMV is electrolessly plated with Ni, aligned onto a gold-coated substrate and then coated with the desired ALD available material 104 . Using this procedure Li-ion batteries were fabricated with V2O5 and shown to increase the areal capacity ~8X when TMV was used to increase the surface area 105 . Combining the bottom up TMV/ALD nanostructuring with top down lithography techniques used
in micromachining showed a further 3X increase in the areal capacity as compared to nanostructuring alone 106 . A similar process was also used to make flexible solid-state super capacitors based on RuO2/TMV 107 .
Simultaneous with the TMV studies another protein-based structure, ferritin,
was examined 96 . Ferritin, like TMV, is a well-studied, 12 nm, hollow, globular protein that contains 24 subunits. Ferritin is tasked with moving iron around in biological systems and as such the hollow core contains ferrihydrite. When ferritin is carrying its iron load it is referred to as such, i.e. ferritin, however, if the iron core is removed through the 3-4 Å channels located at the subunit boundaries it is referred to as apoferritin. Deposition on ferritin with Al2O3 and TiO2 led to ferritin embedded in a thin film but more importantly showed similar results to that of TMV with the ferrit in also being robust enough to survive the harsh processing conditions. A follow up study with apoferritin was conducted with TiO2 and showed that by choosing the appropriate pretreatment (i.e. drying with NaCl or not) deposition would occur entirely on the outside or also on the inside 108 . After the deposition the spherical structure was maintained though it is expected that the process may have been more CVD-like or at least contain significant amounts of parasitic-CVD due the omnipresent water tightly bound to the protein structure.
A third protein structure, the S-layer, which is a molecular sheet with regularly
arranged pores that self-assembles from the proteins of cell envelopes of certain bacteria when the assembly conditions are properly controlled 109, 110 . For the purpose of ALD the s-layers had to first be passivated with octadecyltrichlorosilane (ODTS) to prevent any deposition on the S-layer itself as has been shown in area-selective ALD 111, 112 . With the S-layer passivated ALD HfO2 was deposited and forced grow only in the pores of the S-layer 110 . After the process was completed the S-layer was removed by thermally annealing in air at 600°C leaving behind regularly arranged HfO2 nanodots.
Pieces of proteins can also be used to form biotemplates. Peptides are small
subunits of proteins consisting of at least two amino acids that can be electrospun into incredibly long, even into the millimeter range, fibers as in the case for diphenylalanine 113 . In a series of publications highly entangled diphenylalanine fibers were coated with TiO2 and calcinated at 300°C to form hollow TiO2 nanostructures 114 . The calcination step had the additional advantage of annealing the TiO2 into the anatase phase. Various properties of the hollow TiO2 fibers were tested including, wettability, which proved to be UV switchable, rheological, and electrochemical 114 .
The high surface area of the entangled nanoribbons combined with the well-
known material properties of TiO2 led to far more interesting applications in energy storage and generation. Li-ion batteries were fabricated using powders of the TiO2 nanoribbons mixed with standard carbon black and binders 115 . The batteries showed excellent columbic efficiency, high rate stability, and a relatively high discharge capacity of 200 mAh/g as compared to standard commercially available TiO2 powders. The same structures were also used to make dye sensitized solar cells (DSSC) 116 . For this application the nanoribbons were calcinated at two different temperatures 400°C and 500°C, which resulted in either an entirely anatase TiO2 structure or a mixture of anatase and rutile TiO2. The power conversion efficiency of the two structures was compared with the mixed anatase-rutile structure having the superior efficiency at 3.8% as compared to 2.4% for the pure anatase phase. Further comparison was made between the mixed phase nanoribbons and conventional TiO2 powder (which also had the mixed anatase-rutile phase). The nanoribbons were shown to comparable, if not slightly superior, to the powder with reported conversion efficiencies of 3.8% and 3.6% respectively.
4.2 Natural Fibers
One of the most common structures found in nature is the fiber. Fibrous
materials exist in everything from plant stems and leaves to animal and human muscles. On the nanoscale DNA represents the most common fibrous structure and is considered by scientists to have significant potential in a broad range of future applications. DNA was coated by ALD out of shear curiosity but also to functionalize carbon nanotubes for the fabrication of transistors 97, 117 . Without functionalization CNTs cannot be coated by ALD as there are no, or at least very few, available reaction sites to begin the reaction 118 . Functionalization can be done in several ways including the introduction of defects 39 or, as one group showed, by wrapping a CNT with DNA. The DNA was shown to attach to the NT through π-stacking and resulted in an effective new surface for the ALD precursors to react with. Using the DNA wrapped CNTs transistors were made by uniformly coating with HfO2, a process which would not be possible if a significant number of defects had to be created first.
Cellulose represents another fibrous structure with the added benefit of being
renewable and carbon neutral. Cellulose is a polysaccharide composed of individual dglucose units and is of particular interest for a large variety of reasons. It is the most abundant biopolymer on earth and exists in several different polymorphs cellulose I (mainly from plants), cellulose II (bacterial algae), cellulose III, and cellulose IV. Cellulose I, the primary source for cotton and paper, has a hierarchical structure of fibers, micro-fibrillated fibers, and micro-fibrils each containing both crystalline and amorphous regions and are largely bound together through hydrogen bonds. Given that cellulose is a virtually unlimited resource, adaptations of cellulose for a particular technology or application are very appealing.
The first work combining ALD and cellulose was done with paper. Laboratory
filter papers were coated with TiO2, replicas (where the cellulose substrate is thermally
decomposed in a post annealing step) and composite TiO2/cellulose structures (no thermal decomposition) were fabricated. The resulting structures were shown to be photocatalytic by monitoring the formation of Ag nanoparticles through photoreduction of Ag(I) ions. 119 Additional studies with replicated cellulose was conducted using Ir decorated Al2O3/cellulose and TiO2/cellulose, in these cases the photocatalytic activity was monitored through methylene blue degradation 120 . Similar work was done using nanocellulose to create core/shell aero gels and nanotubes 121
Transitions of the wetting properties of cotton fibers were studied as a function
of ALD cycle numbers. It was shown that the fibers become hydrophobic after only a few cycles of a TMA/H2O and again hydrophilic with the application of a few more cyles; the authors further noted qualitatively similar results with other fiber systems modified with TiO2, TiN, and ZnO though no data were presented. 122, 123 The conductivity of ZnO coated cotton and polypropylene were also studied. 124
4.4 Biomaterials as pattern templates ALD’s ability to conformally coat comple three-dimensional substrates allows
for structural mimicry of biological systems at an unprecedented level. These biological structures have the advantage of million years of evolution to craft them perfect to their particular application. One of the first structures to be studied in terms of ALD mimicking was butterfly wings 125-128 . Butterfly wings are interesting from a physical standpoint as they can display an incredibly wide range of colors based entirely on the nanostructure of the wings as opposed to chemical based color that relies on dyes, as can be seen in Figure 11(a-c). The periodicity of the wing structure leads to a natural periodic grating thus creating a photonic structure. Photonic structures are of considerable interest in a wide variety of fields for applications in optical computing, fiber optics, etc. and can be difficult or expensive to create synthetically.
One of the first butterfly wing structure explored was that of the morpho
peleides that has a naturally occurring bright blue color 125, 128 . The wings were used as templates and coated with varying thickness of Al2O3 from 10 nm to 40 nm. The authors were able to show that the color of the replica could be tuned from green to purple depending on the thickness of the Al2O3. The same group also studied the wetting properties of these wings 128 . It was shown that the wing would go from super hydrophobic to hydrophilic when the wings were coated with 30 nm of Al2O3. A second species of butterfly the Papilio blumei, that has a green color naturally with blue colored tails, was also studied 126, 127 . Again the periodicity of the nanostructure of the wing is what defines the color and in the case of this species the wings have embedded air cavities. In this work the wings were coated with TiO2, which has a higher index of refraction than the chitin-wing substrate. A model was constructed for simulating the photonic properties for the two possible ways of deposition, on top and bottom, and conformally throughout the structure. Good agreement was shown for the spectral data between the modeled and measured results for both cases. When defects or cracks are present the ALD precursors can easily diffuse into the interior of the structure and coat the air pockets. The main difference between the two cases was the shift of the main reflection peak at 524 nm. If the wings were coated top and bottom the main peak shifted towards larger wavelengths at a rate of 1 nm per nm of TiO2 deposited. If, however, the air pockets are also coated then the main peak shifts at 12 nm per nm of TiO2 deposited. Unfortunately there did not appear to be a way to experimentally select between the two cases.
Beyond the photonic properties witnessed in the butterfly wing studies ordered
nanostructures are also known to have significant control over wettability. The naturally occurring ordered structure of the butterfly wing is hydrophobic, which is certainly important to the survival of the insect and may be due, at least in part, to the natural wax
coating. The hydrophobic properties of the morpho peleides butterfly wing was coated with Al2O3 and compared to water strider legs 128 . In their native state both the butterfly wing and the water strider leg are anti-wetting and self-cleaning, the so-called Cassie state 129
. Once the materials were coated with hydrophilic Al2O3 the butter fly wing
switched from the Cassie state to Wenzel state, which differs due to contact angle hysteresis 130 , while the water strider legs retains the Cassie state. This was explained by the fact that the butterfly wing’s structure e ists mainly in plane, while the water strider leg has structure out of plane, and is able to trap air. There despite the coating the Cassie state is retained.
Another chitin based biomaterial studied with ALD coatings was sea mouse
bristles 131 . The bristles of the sea mouse, as seen in Figure 12, are hairs and spines that are centimeters long and contain continuous hollow channels with a diameter of 200 nm. Much like periodic structures found in butterfly wings, the pores in bristles are also very regular and exhibit iridescence in the blue/green for the hairs and a red/orange for the spines. Despite the interesting photonic properties so far the bristles have only been used as templates resulting in nanotubes with wall thicknesses of 20 nm. Unfortunately the length of the tubes could not be accurately measured due to difficulty in dissolution of the bristles.
A more common biological structure was studied when replicas of house hold
fly eyes were fabricated with Al2O3 132 . Fly eyes are highly complicated structures that consist of smaller subunits called ommatidia, which themselves contain individual nanostructures. Fly eyes show antireflective properties above 400 nm wavelengths with a reflection peak at 330 nm. After the deposition and removal of the template by annealing at 500°C the replica fly eyes show similar anti-reflection properties only shifted from 330 nm to 375 nm.
Finally a legume, the fruit of wisteria, from the pea family, seen in Figure 13,
which has tubular micro scale hairs called trichomes, was coated with 60 nm of Al2O3 133 . The layer of Al2O3 served as a support layer for the fabrication of a ZnAl layered double hydroxide film. Next the structure was calcinated resulting in a mixed metal oxide (MMO) framework that contained both phases of ZnO as well as the spinel ZnAl2O4. The MMO structure showed a significantly higher surface area as compared to a powdered sample, 134.32 m 2 /g as compared to 55.44 m 2 /g for the powder. When used as a photo catalyst this enhanced surface area of the MMO showed higher degradation rates for two dyes, poly{1-4[4-(3-carboxy-4hydroxyphenylazo)benzenesulfonamido]-1,2-ethanediyl} sodium salt (PAZO) and sulfurhodamine B, when exposed to UV radiation.
4.4 Coated Synthetic Soft Materials One of the most well researched areas in terms of hybrid materials from ALD is
inorganic coating on synthetic and/or organic polymers. In fact this area is so large that it could comprise a rather large review of its own and, as mentioned in the introduction
arsons’ group has published a smaller re iew focusing on their work in the area 33 .
Wading into this rather vast area allows several possible approaches in regards to division of information. One possibility is through considering the organic substrate itself, however even this is a considerable amount of information to review and has been tabulated elsewhere 134 . Some of the more common polymers used as organic substrates are polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) 135-141 , polyethylene terephthalate (PET) 142-146 , polypropylene 122, 123, 136, 140, 147-149 , polyimide (kapton) 144, 150-152 , polyamide (nylon 6) 148, 153 , poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) 154, 155 , poly(vinyl alcohol) 156 , and polytetrafluoroethylene (Teflon) 135 . One could also consider the functionality of the polymer substrate, polypropylene, polyvinyl alcohol, and/or polyamide 6 which have no
reactive groups, hydroxyl groups, and carbonyl and amine groups respectively. For the sake of this section of this review we will focus on a few of the many possible applications which include, but certainly not limited to; surface energy modification 135 , gas diffusion barriers 142, 144 , and encapsulation of OLEDs 141 .
An interesting set of experiments were conducted using Teflon, Kapton, and
PMMA in an attempt to imitate and prevent mass loss and erosion due to exposure to the harsh conditions experienced by polymers in low-earth orbit 139 . It was shown that by coating the samples with thin-films of Al2O3, TiO2, or combinations of both that the polymer could be protected from erosion when exposed to atomic oxygen. Interestingly the minimum number of cycles required to provide adequate protection differed based on the substrate. Kapton only required 15 cycles of Al2O3 to prevent degradation, while Teflon needed at least 75 cycles. The authors speculated that this drastic difference was most likely due to large differences in the nucleation period between the two substrates. The mass-loss of PMMA was also studied as a function of exposure to vacuum ultraviolet light. In this case it was shown that by coating the PMMA with 20 cycles of Al2O3 followed by 100 cycles of TiO2 showed very little mass loss after nearly 1000 minutes of exposure.
Cotton and paper were coated with conductive ZnO to make highly conductive
fibrous materials and allowed for the fabrication of an all fiber-based capacitor 124 . The ZnO coated fibers showed a conductivity of 24 S cm -1 , which was comparable to standard thin film conductivities but significantly lower than ALD W coated quartz fibers with conductivities of 1150 S cm -1 . Using these fibers an all fiber capacitor was fabricated as shown in Figure 14. Two ~3 cm 2 pieces of quartz fiber cloth were coated with 200 cycles of ALD W. The dielectric layer was a non-woven polypropylene fiber and the system was shown to ha e a permitti ity of εr ~2.2 to 2.8. More interestingly was the fact that the fibrous capacitor system readily allowed the absorption of a variety
of liquids that alter the dielectric constant having a dramatic effect on the overall device. The authors used H2O, ethyl alcohol, and isopropyl alcohol and studied the resulting devices as a function of frequency.
Bilayers of TiO2 and Al2O3, 5 nm each, were used to coat Kevlar (poly(p-
phenylene terephthalamide), PPTA) fibers and shown to increase the cut-resistance of the fibers 157 . Kevlar is commonly used in bulletproof vests but has the disadvantage of not being particularly protective against cuts or stabbing. When coated with either Al2O3 or TiO2 individually very little improvement is seen as a function of cycle number. When, combined however the bilayers of TiO2/Al2O3 show a 30% increase in the cut resistance. Based on XPS and in-situ FTIR the authors suggest that the TMA may be cutting into the PPTA backbone and cleaving the phenyl-N bond and causing the fibers to shrink, whereas the TiO2 process does not seem to alter the PPTA backbone at all. Therefore the bilayer of TiO2 first prevents the Al2O3 precursor from damaging the backbone leading the improved mechanical properties.
Non-woven mats, i.e. fibrous material assemblies that show little or no
preferential ordering, of either polypropylene or nylon-6 were masked by compression between two aluminum plates 153 . ZnO was then deposited through the mask using the standard precursors DEZ and H2O. The diffusion of the precursors and thus the depth of ZnO penetration into the mats were studied as a function of dose, temperature, number of cycles, and mask compression. It was shown that the diffusion could be controlled through the choice of substrate and the tuning of these properties.
The interaction of the precursors with the backbone of a polymer structure and
other subsurface areas begins to show where the difference between coating and infiltration starts to blur with soft materials. Even when using standard parameters for coating are used, depending on the temperature and the polymer used, the precursor can diffuse into these regions and have dramatic effects on the bulk properties 123, 158 . This
phenomenon has launched a relatively new area of research where these properties are targeted for manipulation through the vapor phase deposition processes discussed here and is the subject of our next chapter.

sections.heading: 5. Top Down: Vapor Phase Infiltration
sections.text:
Traditionally top down fabrication methods have been limited to lithography-
based techniques such as, electron beam, photo, and others. These techniques are generally good for large area patterning, are nominally 2D in nature, and widely used in the semiconductor industry for the fabrication of various computer components. ALD allows an entirely new approach to the top down methodology where the material rather than the structure is altered. Bearing in mind that ALD is a chemical process involving temporal separation of the precursors, it is self-explaining that, dependent on the process parameters set, the substrate will be exposed to a reactive precursor for a certain period of time. An extended exposure time in conjunction with solid substrates will have no serious effect, besides a better step coverage if high aspect ratio structures are used and precursor diffusion plays a serious role. However, if soft materials such as polymers are used as substrates, the reactive precursors may penetrate the macromolecular bulk and precipitate or interact in subsurface regions of the polymer. In fact, ALD precursors reacting below the surface of polymer substrates was first observed by Wilson et al for a variety of different polymers applying ALD processes of Al2O3 to polystyrene, polypropylene, poly(methyl methacrylate), polyethylene, and poly(vinyl chloride) 136 The subsurface reaction was witnessed as an undesired ‘side effect’ of the deposition process and this very important paper aims at stressing the fact that ALD is in principle compatible with polymeric substrates, but one has to be aware that both process and resulting material may not be exactly what one initially expected.
However, the finding that ALD precursors may penetrate the polymer and
interact with subsurface regions enabled a completely new and exciting application of metal-organic precursors for the modification of soft materials such as synthetic and bioorganic polymers at the molecular scale. The first studies have, for example, shown dramatic changes in the bulk mechanical properties.
Strictly speaking, the top-down modification of polymers by ALD is not an
ALD process. There is no self-saturation of the surface with the precursors, as part of them diffuses into the bulk, and there is no precise control of the growth of films, as part of the film is buried in the substrate. Still, the infiltration methodology relies on the same technical principles being, the sequential supply of vaporized precursors and solvent-free operation as it is performed in vacuum, qualifying it as an ALD-based infiltration methodology.
Initially, the intentional infiltration was performed with couples of precursors, in
the same manner as an ALD process, just with extended exposure times. In order to differentiate the ALD coating from the infiltration process, this process developed by Lee et al was named Multiple Pulsed Vapor Phase Infiltration (MPI), see Figure 15. Subsequently, Jur et al followed a similar strategy with modified pulsing, which was named Sequential Vapor Infiltration (SVI) and Peng et al named their material selective infiltration of block copolymers Sequential Infiltration Synthesis (SIS). In the following we will refer to these processes as ´infiltration´ only in order to avoid confusing the reader.

sections.heading: 5.1 Natural Polymers
sections.text:
The initial work describing the infiltration mechanism as possible means to alter
materials showed significant changes in mechanical properties of spider silk 37, 55 , as seen in Figure 16. Extended exposure times resulted in diffusion of the precursors into
the bulk of the spider silk. The process was performed with a precursor couple, the metal-organic and organometallic precursors, respectively, and water vapor. The presence of metal in the bulk of the spider silk after the infiltration process was evidenced by TEM-EDX investigations on microtomed slices. The tenfold increased toughness of the silk is, however, not a result of the presence of around 3 wt.% metal (ions) in the bulk, but of the chemical interaction of precursor and substrate. XRD characterization and the analysis of the full width at the half maximum (FWHM) of the protein signature has, for example, shown that the reactive metal containing precursors decrease the size of the beta-sheets of the protein fiber, which eventually enhances both stress and strain upon tensile tests simultaneously. Solid state NMR further indicated an interaction of aluminum with the protein backbone, crosslinking the strands. The impact of the organometallic precursor on the hydrogen bonds present in the spider silk was further investigated in a recent in-situ Raman spectroscopy study of infiltrated spider silk 159 . A similar change in the mechanical properties occurred after treatment of collagen fiber networks extracted from eggshell membranes 160 . The toughness of the infiltrated collagen membranes increased 3-fold, which is a result of the cross-linking of the collagen fibers with the infiltrated metal ions. According to the data obtained from XRD, the metal ions appeared to distribute in a regular fashion along the helices of the collagen, see Figure 17, owing to the repeating motif of the amino acid blocks.
For comparison, the infiltrated spider silk and the collagen membranes were
treated by ALD-infiltration and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) 91 . The intention of this experiment was to clarify whether or not the increase in toughness stands in direct relation to the thin ceramic layer deposited on the surface of the biomaterials in either case, infiltration or coating. Indeed, it turned out that the coatings have an effect on the mechanical properties of the treated biomaterials, but the effect is mainly related to the incresase of the initial Youngs Modulus, while the simultaneous increase in stress and
strain of the treated materials with respect to their native counterparts was only observed upon infiltration. This further confirmed the findings described before, namely the reactive precursors interact chemically in various ways with the bulk or the subsurface areas of the substrate.
The chemical interaction of precursors with substrates was further shown with
chemically simpler and better defined substrates, namely the so-called J-aggregates that are self-assembled fibers consisting of porphyrin rings 161 . An infiltration of such Jaggregates with DEZ resulted in a metalation of the porphyrin rings with Zn(II). The infiltration has in this case proven that even an alternative synthetic aspect of this process can be considered, since the metalation occurred in a nearly quantitative manner in a solvent free environment within only a few minutes. Interestingly, this process was rapid and nearly quantitative with DEZ, while no significant metalation was observed upon the use of TMA or TIP. Apparently, the Zn has a higher affinity to the functional cavities of the used porphyrin.
A study similar to the spider silk work, discussed above, was also conducted
with cellulose fibers 162 . In these experiments single precursors, namely DEZ and TMA, were used rather than the standard precursor pairs. The metal infiltrated cellulose showed significant changes in the mechanical properties as a function of cycle number and precursor choice, as seen in Figure 18. Infiltration with DEZ led to 2X and 2.5X increase in the ultimate tensile strength and elastic modulus respectively, while TMA infiltration did little to affect the same two properties.

sections.heading: 5.2 Synthetic Polymers
sections.text:
The finding that ALD precursors can penetrate into polymeric substrates during
processing led to a series of investigations on the control and chemistry of this type of process. Initial work by Parson´s group describes the temperature-dependence of the
infiltration of polypropylene (PP) and the subsurface growth of alumina particles, a schematic of which is shown in Figure 19 123 . PP does not contain oxygen groups that can be attacked by TMA, therefore a true hybrid material formation, as was the case for spider silk (see section 5.1) was not observed. However, at processing temperatures of 90 ºC, the TMA precursor could still diffuse into the polymer and become trapped in the subsurface region until it became hydrolyzed to alumina with a water vapor pulse. This eventually resulted in the formation of nanoparticles, which had a size variation as a function of the number of processing cycles. The effect of the temperature was ascribed to the thermal expansion of the polymer, decreasing the density of the substrate and allowing enhanced in-diffusion of the TMA, thus being dominantly driven by physical effects.
An opposite dependency of the diffusion on the processing temperature was
found while applying infiltration processes of TMA to polyamide 6 (PA6) substrates as shown in Figure 20 158, 163 . Here, processing temperatures of 60 ºC yielded deeper precursor penetration and thus thicker subsurface hybrid layer. This effect is ascribed to the likely higher density of the hybrid material formed by TMA and PA6 at elevated temperatures, which, presumably, hindered diffusion of TMA into deeper regions of the substrate. PA6 contains functional groups such as carbonyls, amines, and those are potentially chemically interacting with TMA. Additionally, water and further byproducts of the polymerization reaction trapped in the bulk of the polymer may contribute to the barrier formation upon chemical reaction with TMA. Besides the temperature, the dosing of the precursors plays an important role as well. Quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) records show significant impact of the dosing and exposure times on the mass gain of the infiltrated PA6.
The mentioned experiments already indicate that the polymer infiltration
through ALD is a significantly more complex process than ALD itself. First, one has to
consider the move from 2D substrates to 3D substrates. As a consequence, the rather simple idealized view of saturative adsorption of precursors on a substrate surface becomes invalid. One has to account for the bulk of the substrate being a surface wherever the ALD precursor can penetrate. This, on the other hand, poses a serious problem for the estimation of the necessary amount of precursor to be supplied as such bulk “surface” cannot be easily measured. In fact, most of the reported work describes infiltration and subsurface growth in undersaturative conditions as the precursor might either chemically interact with the substrate and block further infiltration as in the example of the PA6, not enough precursor is supplied, or not enough time is permitted for a saturative infiltration. An idea on how much time is needed for a homogeneous infiltration is shown in the work of Gong et al 56 , who soaked fibers of various polyesters with TMA or TiCl4 for up to 18 hours in order to obtain porous alumina or titania monoliths after subsequent calcination and removal of the polymer matrix, as shown in Figure 21. The required duration of pulsing and exposure times are functions of the macroscopic morphologies of the substrates and their densities, which are not of relevance if standard ALD coating is being performed. However, the most serious difference to the coating by ALD is related to the chemistry of the substrate, which has a great influence on the process and the resulting material.
For a better understanding of the types of chemical interactions involved in the
hybridization of ALD precursors with various polymers, a screening of the reactivity of ALD precursors with a variety of polymers was performed. The studies covered the infiltration mainly of TMA into PP, polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), polyamide-6 (PA6), various polyesters (PBT, PET, PLA), polycarbonate (PC), polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) and polyethylene oxide (PEO) 33, 164 . The occurring chemical reactions were characterized by in-situ infrared spectroscopy.
The outcome of this series of experiments can be summarized as follows; those
polymers, which contain nucleophilic functional groups such as carbonyl, esters, ethers, etc. easily chemically react with TMA upon infiltration. The TMA, being a strong Lewis acid, attacks the oxygen of the functional site, which could be clearly seen from the differential FTIR spectra recorded in situ. The decrease of characteristic C=O and C-O peaks and the simultaneous occurrence of Al-O signatures indicate covalent binding of aluminum to oxygen and in some cases even scission of polymer chains. Insertion of TMA into Al-O-Al as well as ligand exchange reactions may occur, in dependence of the particular polymer used. Similar results were also found for ordered surfactant polymer films. 165 The chemical reactivity of the ALD precursors with the functionalities of the polymers eventually allowed the synthesis of mesoporous metal oxides after removal of the surfactant template. In the case of polymers without intrinsic functional groups, such as PP, the nucleation of alumina in the subsurface area is presumably related to confinement of TMA in the polymer and reaction with the water supplied with the subsequent pulse. However, even in the case of polymers without functional groups, bulk interactions of ALD precursors and polymers can occur. An example of such a reaction was evidenced upon infiltrating poly-tetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) with DEZ. 166 PTFE is considered to have extraordinary chemical and thermal stability. In principle, no chemical interaction of such a polymer with an ALD precursor is expected, at least at temperatures below 200 ºC. However, infiltration with DEZ resulted in a material with high brittleness and Raman spectra showed serious modification to the polymer backbone. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggest that DEZ may partly decompose in the vapor phase and form numerous reactive species, which possess high enough reactivity to attack the polymer backbone, preferably at defect sites. Two types of reactions may likely occur, an insertion of Zn
into a C-F bond or bridging PTFE chains with Zn-O-Zn bonds at their defect sites. The case of cross-linking may be the reason for the change in the mechanical properties.
The possibility to infiltrate ALD precursors into polymers and finding that the
functionality of the polymer defines whether or not a chemical reaction with the precursor will take place resulted in several investigations on the selective reaction of ALD precursors with functional domains in block copolymers. Initially, Wang et al produced nanorods of polystyrene-block-poly(2-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P2VP), confined within the pores of anodic alumina (AAO). After removal of the P2VP domains, mesoporous nanorods were obtained and used as substrates for the infiltration. The DEZ infiltration resulted in coating of the outer and inner surfaces of the mesoporous nanorods, however, the internal surfaces were coated with lower thicknesses, which is presumably related to barrier properties of the developing outer coating of the nanorods.
A more practical block copolymer system, as shown in Figure 22, was used by
Peng et al 167, 168 . The copolymer consisted of PS and PMMA and therefore contained both nonreactive and reactive polymer domains at the same time. A number of infiltration processes were applied to thin films of this block copolymer, resulting in the selective formation of inorganic phases within the PMMA domains. Eventually, after plasma treatment and thus removal of the polymer, the domain structure of the PMMA was reproduced with Al 2 O 3 , TiO 2 , ZnO, SiO 2 and W with high fidelity. Also for such diffusion reaction, exposure times and the resulting dynamics of the precursor-polymer substrate system are of importance. Gong et al showed that TMA could diffuse through the PP sheath of a bi-component fiber and react with the PMMA core if long enough ALD cycles were applied 169 . Short cycles, however, resulted in coating of the outer surface of the fiber. An application potential for infiltrated PMMA was shown by Tseng et al, a diagram of which is shown in Figure 23, who investigated the etch resistance of PMMA-patterns on substrates before and after infiltration with TMA. Indeed, the
infiltrated PMMA showed an improvement of the etch resistance by a factor of 37, which shows that the polymer is seriously reinforced by the introduced inorganic material 170 .
More recently, and in a similar vein as the self-organized block co-polymers
discussed above a carboxylic end-functionalized poly(3-hexylthiophene) was used such that an ordered array of amorphous and crystalline regions was created, as shown in Figure 24 171 . Here, the (P3HT-COOH) was spin coated onto a substrate and gradually cooled allowing the crystallization into a well-ordered structure. It was then shown that the standard DEZ/H 2 O process diffused into and reacted with the amorphous domains of the polymer creating a lamellae structure. The hybrid structure was shown to behave as a solar cell with the ZnO acting as the electron donor and the P3HT as the acceptor.
The current state of the art in terms of infiltration from the vapor phase clearly
shows that (bio)polymeric materials can be seriously altered in their properties. However, besides some initial hints on the chemical interactions and mechanical properties of the resulting hybrids, the knowledge base remains poor and enormous effort is needed in order to better understand the systems and to be able to predict the outcome once a polymer-precursor combination is considered. Much of the intuition might be derived from nature as many natural systems make use of soft matter and inorganics in certain combinations in order to achieve specific functionalities. However, the systems will not be directly comparable, since the synthetic routes in nature and with ALD strongly differ and the resulting materials and properties, as well as the target applications will be different as well.

sections.heading: 6. Future Directions
sections.text:
In view of the growing demand on functional materials of various types,
strategies to tune properties and design novel materials have become increasingly
important. Especially for emerging applications, that involve micro- or nanoscale control of dimensions, ALD/MLD technology may have a significant impact on the development of specific solutions.
Since the current technological development moves towards smaller, but also
flexible electronics, ALD/MLD are fairly unique in terms of benefit for the development as they combine several advantages for new functional materials development. One the one hand there is the Ångstrom scale thickness control and on the other hand the possibility to blend inorganic materials with organics or vice versa with extraordinary precision in the composition of the constituents. Thus, the application range of ALD and related processing based on the same technology may become vast but only with significantly more work and creativity.
The examples shown in this manuscript are indicative of the power of this way
of synthesizing materials. A great knowledge base is already built worldwide, especially for depositing inorganic materials. The organic counterpart MLD is being increasingly covered through scholarly contributions of a steadily growing community. However, still too little is known about the chemistry involved during the process and the resulting physical properties of the products. Therefore it is utmost important to widen the spectrum of combinations in order to be able to address real technological challenges with the bespoken hybrid materials. Without any doubt, thin films, which are hybrid in terms of composition and/or their functionality, will be implemented in emerging devices and ALD/MLD will in many cases be the method of choice.

metadata.abstractText: The ability to produce or alter materials to obtain drastically different or improved properties has been the driving goal of materials science since its inception. Combining multiple elements, compounds, or materials while maintaining the beneficial aspects of each constituent is a complex problem often involving highly interdisciplinary research. Hybrid materials, i.e. materials that incorporate organic and inorganic parts, have become popular in a variety of fields. Though not entirely new, the modern embodiment of hybrid materials has led to a large variety of new materials and techniques to produce them. One of the most recent being combination of atomic layer deposition (ALD), which produces inorganic materials, and molecular layer deposition (MLD), which produces organic materials. Furthermore, a variation on these techniques, commonly referred to as infiltration, has allowed for the modification of a variety of natural and synthetic polymers with surprising results related to their bulk 2 mechanical properties. In this review three approaches are taken. First, hybrid materials through bottom-up combinations of ALD and MLD are reviewed, focusing on the process and properties of the resulting materials. Second, the modification of biomaterials through coating is discussed, and finally the relatively new concept of vapor phase infiltration is considered as a new and unique method to produce hybrid materials from a top down perspective.
